Group.title: System Security Services Daemon
Group.description:
The System Security Services Daemon (SSSD) is a system daemon that provides access to different identity and authentication providers such as Red Hat's IdM, Microsoft's AD, openLDAP, MIT Kerberos, etc. It uses a common framework that can provide caching and offline support to systems utilizing SSSD. SSSD using caching to reduce load on authentication servers permit offline authentication as well as store extended user user data.
For more information, see

Rule.title: Install the SSSD Package
Rule.description: The sssd package should be installed.

Rule.title: Enable the SSSD Service
Rule.description: The SSSD service should be enabled.

Rule.title: Configure SSSD's Memory Cache to Expire
Rule.description: SSSD's memory cache should be configured to set to expire records after 1 day. To configure SSSD to expire memory cache, set memcache_timeout to 86400 under the [nss] section in /etc/sssd/sssd.conf. For example: [nss] memcache_timeout = 86400

ocil.clause: it does not exist or is not configured properly

Rule.ocil: To verify that SSSD's in-memory cache expires after a day, run the following command: $ sudo grep memcache_timeout /etc/sssd/sssd.conf If configured properly, output should be memcache_timeout = 86400.
Rule.rationale: If cached authentication information is out-of-date, the validity of the authentication information may be questionable.

Rule.title: Configure SSSD to Expire Offline Credentials
Rule.description: SSSD should be configured to expire offline credentials after 1 day. To configure SSSD to expire offline credentials, set offline_credentials_expiration to 1 under the [nss] section in /etc/sssd/sssd.conf. For example: [nss] offline_credentials_expiration = 1

ocil.clause: it does not exist or is not configured properly

Rule.ocil: To verify that SSSD expires offline credentials, run the following command: $ sudo grep offline_credentials_expiration If configured properly, output should be offline_credentials_expiration = 1
Rule.rationale: If cached authentication information is out-of-date, the validity of the authentication information may be questionable.

Rule.title: Configure SSSD to Expire SSH Known Hosts
Rule.description: SSSD should be configured to expire keys from known SSH hosts after 1 day. To configure SSSD to known SSH hosts, set ssh_known_hosts_timeout to 86400 under the [nss] section in /etc/sssd/sssd.conf. For example: [nss] ssh_known_hosts_timeout = 86400

ocil.clause: it does not exist or is not configured properly

Rule.ocil: To verify that SSSD expires known SSH host keys, run the following command: $ sudo grep ssh_known_hosts_timeout If configured properly, output should be ssh_known_hosts_timeout = 86400
Rule.rationale: If cached authentication information is out-of-date, the validity of the authentication information may be questionable.
